reviewText:
Early Access Review

I decided to give this game a try since I happened upon it on the release date and I enjoy simulations like this.  I must say, I'm very impressed so far.

You're given a nice storyline to begin with and continue from there.  The tutorial will get you familiar with the basic aspect of the game, but from there you're on your own and I like it.  This game is definitely challenging right off the bat and that is something I was looking for.

If you enjoy simulations and having to plan out almost every move from the very beginning, you should give this a try.  It looks quite promising for the future assuming the devs can keep providing updates.

Some personal thoughts/experiences:
- I feel as though the combat is almost too difficult at the start.  I found myself struggling even on the first couple of tracks out of the first town.  After a few tries I was able to figure out what needed to be done, but it was very challenging.
- I don't think you are given enough money to begin with and/or aren't rewarded enough for completing missions.  I was struggling for cash to even afford the licenses needed to get to the first few cities.
- Hardcore mode is turned on by default; I think it should be turned off
- Dialog windows could use some work, maybe separate chat boxes instead?
- After you select a target and give it a command, you need to reselect the target.  I think if you select a target it should stay selected until you escape out and/or select somewhere in the field
- Reload times are way too long
- The Perks are an interesting aspect to the game, though I think some of the power-ups need better descriptions (i.e. What does Willpower do?)

I will be playing this game again and look forward to what the devs have in store for the future.  For now, I think maybe turning DOWN the diffuculty of the battles would be a good idea in order to explore more of the game and allow for a bit more income in the early game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had previously posted a negative review during the earlier stages of the game's development, noting a number of game-breaking bugs. In the months since then, the game's developers have worked hard to improve it, with occasional but comprehensive updates happening every few months. The devs were very responsive to feedback and addressed the issues that players had been bringing up. The game has really gone up in quality since it was released, and I'd highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Roguelikeish simulation, like sorta?

Like:
*A decent amount of mechanics that keeps you on edge without feeling overwhelming
*Plenty of quests to do
*Clear goals
*Train customization
*Reputations
*Optional history lessons

Want:
*More quest types (transport important documents, trigger ambushes)
*More advanced reputation system (competing cities, gain or lose reputation when doing quests for certain cities etc)
*Combat needs some polishing (controls needs to be improved and/or add pause for optimal min-maxing)
*More/better information (a lot of stuff has tooltips but not everything. a game like this pretty much needs info on everything BEFORE purchase/recruitment etc)

Overall a good game. I do recommend it even in its current state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very enjoyable Indie game (said an exigent old gamer). 8/10 at current state. Can be perfectible and can become a must have if suffisent content is added, and I hope it will.

Pros:
- Complete : perfect mix between trading, adventure (main and secundary quests), action, which reminds greatest & lost 90' game
- Well balanced
- Good ergonomy, simple but enjoyable graphics
- Nice storyline, faithful to american history

Cons:
- Expensive. Such indie game is rather 10€ worth, not 25
- Some few bugs remaining. Some hitboxes/ergonomy to be improved during fights
- Ridiculously too short ! please add far far more content after the early access...
- Lack of competition. There is no other way to lose except exceeding time limit to complete main quest. Economy is not a serious threat as you always can get profit. A competition mode or something with some others IA players is lacking.


Looking forward the finished game with more content and fixed bug. I also hope it will not rely on multiple DLC. This kind of game deserve to be suported.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an Early Access Game Bounty Train is ridiculously fun.

However i'm not sure it's worth it's current £18.99 price tag, there's just not that much game play in it. I finished the campaign in a little over 8 hours and while it is hard it is not hard in a challenging way. Bad guys get more numerous, are much more expensive to pay off and start throwing grenades like they are going out of fashion. Grenades will set your cargo on fire even if they hit the outside of your armored carriage and this just makes the game tedious in the late game.

Reputation just dosn't seem to work properly, I had a run through where I payed off as many people as possible and got my standings with pretty much everyone north of Philadelphia high enough that they would allow me to pass consistently however this seemed to randomly degrade to everyone hating me in no time at all and this strategy leaves you so poor that you have no hope of completing the game in the allotted time frame.

There is no way to avoid fights you know you can't win, creating a game over before the game is over. The only way to wait" in a city is to repair a broken part of you train
date: if your train is full health you can't idle in a town until those bandits pass you have no option but to be confronted by them
recommended: lose a bunch of money or fight them. The game would benefit hugely from being able to wait in towns
hoursPlayed: even for a fee. Twice I got forced into a fight where I knew I would lose and had to restart.\n\nTrading (outside of quests) is pretty much worthless since theres no multiplier for trading distance so you're almost always only trading between stations one stop from each other and the margins are pretty much non existant
voteText: anything with a margin above 5 gold weighs so much you can't even consider trading in it until you have an end game locomotive.\n\nEnough negatives because I can't stress enough in text how much I enjoyed Bounty Train I picked it up on a whim and didn't put it down untill I finished it. You can see the incredible potential of this game just from playing it for 30mins. I am already eagerly awaiting updates and am very excited to see Bounty Train as a finished product."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lets put this into a list

Pro:
For a early acess its a great game
Good info on the trains
Interactive
Combat mechanic is good
Sound quality is interesting
Humerous background characters at stations
Good graphics


Cons:
There really is no pause menu
Pressing esc litterally quits the game
The game has no save function, it has 1 auto save function that saves only when you exit the game (no way to have multiply saves or revert to last save)
Minor grammar errors
Game is to hard on the player early on (Right after the tutorial end bandits or indians which you either have to fight or pay them off that will spawn outside the starting city)
Not enough time is given to complete the story
Weapons shop should already be in the game
There needs to be a check box asking if your sure so you don't add more quests by accident
To many locked railroad paths for the price you have to pay to unlock them
To many bandits out at one time along the same route
Quests check boxs will clutter until you manully exit them out (Needs to be a auto filter to exit them out once you finish the quest)
The game is similar to flappy bird, 1 screw up and you start from the begining no matter where or how far you are in the story because there is no way to recover (auto save, as mention above only brings you to the last city you were in)
Game freezes during gameplay (only when you play for a while this result may varry depending on the computer)
To much combat and enemies are to hard (Basicly you fight bandits 3 times your like ok then fight then 4 more times and they are basicly like kefka in ff6, it takes forever to kill them and its hard to kill them)

Overall the cons may out list the pros but the game is still good, playing it did give me sometimes where I wish there was a save button and got angry beause esc doesn't pause the game and accidently going back to the main menu over and over again, but its a good game, game play is sold, combat is cool but overall this game is more perspective type then anything to be really good you need to get invested in this game or the game will literally tear you to shreds after 1 wrong move, but I recomend this.

Starlight Stamp of Approval

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sometimes it is good to read some FAQs or other dev notes and even reviews.
So I knew in time that the first sequences of this game would be hard to master.

It was a little frustrating nevertheless, but since I am someone who does not give up if something is just difficult (if it is not annoying or simply unmanageable) so I tried until finally I succeeded.
Don’t ask me how, think I just made some things right and fast enough in the end. :)

And here is my advice: keep on trying, since it is worth while continuing.

The setting is great and I like the mix between strategy and sim, so there is action and brain-work at the same time.
I am really looking forward to seeing more of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Against the backdrop of the war that pitched brother against brother, it is your job to gather together your siblings and see the Railroad project begun by your father through to its end.

You'll be trading, wheeling and dealing along the iron tracks that linked the United States together. Along the way you'll be fighting roving bands of outlaws, angry Native American raiders, and facing resistance from the military might of the Confederacy and the Union as the two giants of American history brawl across the shattered nation.

This is an amazing action and strategy game tied in with the best elements of an RPG to present a tour de force of gaming.

I cannot highly recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do love the concept of this game and I've enjoyed playing it thus far.  You play as a son who's father has just died and left you some of his company.  You want the money left to you, but the only way to obtain it is to complete the railroad line across the country.  You start off with a quest to find your siblings.  During this time, you must trade and earn money, upgrade your train and cargo hold, and fight off bandits and the others who are after your goods.  There are a few things that I do beleive need to be worked on:
- there are too many attempts to take my poor little train down.  The only way to avoid this is to pay - and at the start of the game I do not have money or supplie to pay.  I'm unsure if things get better, if for example, I always pay the Indians and they like me.
- Would like everyone to (always) auto attack or a way to pause to assign areas that need protecting/killing.
- Would like the train to move quicker after a battle.  Nothing left, we just drive.  Slowly.  For a long time.  Driving.  Waiting for the track to end.
- I'd like to be able to look at a map and which routes are open before accepting assignments.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OXyOHRHHbK4

Bounty Train is a strategy simulation game where you have to overall win the support of the shareholders over your rival (In a nutshell). The reason you are trying to win shareholders is to stop the opposition from winning and building a train track over Indian Territory. Your father was also against this but mysteriously got killed. Whilst trying to win the shareholders over you are faced with daunting tasks such as being ambushed by bandits, having quests, finding family and carrying passengers from town to town whilst managing the funds you have.

Positives:
+ Easy to learn
+ Quests are enjoyable
+ Customisable train with many workers to hire
+ City hubs are well displayed

Negatives:
- High price
- No achievements
- Not as much control over the train as I would’ve liked

I would recommend this to most people who enjoy strategy and simulation games, however if you’re looking for a more locomotive game where you fully control the locomotive I would choose a different game. In the tutorial it shows you how to use and drive the train, I did not have many scenes in the game where I had control over the train though. The game was very easy to learn though and I enjoyed playing it. If you feel you can stomach the heavy price or wait for the game to be on sale, then by all means get this game. You can watch my preview video for a better idea.

Score: Wait for a sale.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLots of fun! Sid Meirs Railroads meets Pirates
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bounty Train
This game is a really well done mixture of a few of my favorite games:
- FTL
- Pirates!
- Railroad Tycoon
- Commandos
- Transarctica: Arctic Baron (the elderly among us may remember)

Game Features:

Game Modes:
Mainly there are three modes in this game, not counting the tutorial: storyline, sandbox and hardcore.
As you only have one game at a time with only one autosave you have a nice rogue like atmosphere where decisions count and you'll have to live with the consequences. But you get the option to restart a fight if everything goes down south, which is still buggy sometimes as restarting a fight sometimes does not reset your crew and train health or quest status.
Harcore is as harcore says and you have no option to restart at all.
Unless you choose Sandbox mode with no storyline related quests at all you'll probably stick to the necessary routes to complete your story and you'll never visit places far south as of now you always start way up north in Portland.

Storyline:
Placed in the onset of the American Civil War your goal is to fulfill your fathers' legacy: a transcontinetal railroad. Your inheritance: an old train and some cash. So you start out on January 1st, 1861 and have to be finished until July 1st, 1862 or all you and your father worked so hard for is lost.
However, this is the only storyline so far and it is contrary to the games' description linear, totally. Nevertheless placed in a historical setting with restrospective romantic flair it's quite compelling, as it contains elements of Pirates! (find your familiy and get rich in 10 years) and is still difficult to achieve, but tends to get repetitive even if it weren't for those damned linearity memory effects.

Trade:
The most important feature for earning cash. But free trade does not work so well, as regular trade routes are scarce and difficult to come by, so you'll be mostly stuck to trade missions, offered in towns you are allied with, to earn serious cash.
As a result the game looses the kind of freedom that Pirates! offered as mission bound as you are, while trying to master the logistical challanges of picking up weapon crates in New York, delivering them to St.Louis, probably picking up a passenger in Philadelphia and dropping him off in Knoxville, after you earned enough cash from your weapons delivery to pay the fee for unlocking the route to Knoxville, as you have to go there as part of your storyline.

Passenger Transportation:
Consider it more as a bonus. Where do you want to go? Oh, that's (almost) my direction. Hop along, squeeze yourself in between those crates, don't stand in the way and as long as you're here, you can help put out those nasty fires during an ambush and don't expect me to pay for your injuries on drop off.
Seriously passenger transportation works better if regarded as temporarily stocking up your crew with auxillaries with random skills who can assist you during ambushes.

Coal & Train Weight:
Steam engines need coal, that's a kind of well known fact, so here's an interessting concept/limitation to enhace the challenges of the early game. The further you go and the heavier your train the slower you travel and the more coal you need.
But what starts out interessting tends to get repetitive micromangement in the middle and end game, as coal is very cheap and the cost to fully load your coal tender are neglectable. Additionally it is still (a bit) bugged and you can only travel long distance routes with high end locomotives almost regardless of the amount of carriages und cargo you carry.

Trains & Composition:
Now this is a feature we all do enjoy. Earn cash, buy better locomotives and carriages to improve your performance and earn more cash. In addition to coal consumption and pullable cargo weight this offers some serious thoughts on how to configure your train. There is a big variety of locomotives and carriages in the game for the player to choose from to configure the train to your needs. But there is also a trade off to what really is usefull concerning afore mentioned limitations and you'll probably never buy certain vehicles.

Factions:
There are four factions in the game. Union, Confederacy, Indians and Bandits. Improving your factions standing with the Union lowers yours with the Confederacy. Bribing Bandits or paying off Indians improves your standing with them respectively. Failing to fullfill a contract your standing drops. You get the general idea....
In principle it works fine, in reality not. Fending off bandits somehow improved my faction standing with them, leaving me unable to attack them when needed to fulfill my quest. Also my standing with Indians and Bandits seemed to change spontaneously over time. As a matter of fact paying your ambushers is the last and least option you'll ever choose as off now you'll get no reliable long term benfits to count on. But it's good that this options exits as it can save your ♥♥♥.
Fruthermore as you always start out in the north you'll probably always get allied to the Union as a result of the story.

Fight:
This is the FTL/Commandos part of the game but instead of a space ship and nazi soldiers you'll be shooting bandits, indians, KKK members or Confederacy soldiers out of a train. You will get ambushed a lot, really. Ambushing trains must have been some kind of popular sport back in the day. Don't get me wrong as fending off ambushers is great fun and really well done and offers a great feeling of the wild west. Really well done and loads of fun.
But somehow the attackers get carried away and always try to kill you or destroy your train. They never just rob you. Also there are still some minor bugs when attackers don't close in on your train and you have to wait until them timer runs out to continue your journey as it is not possible to reverse your train or exit it. Now those would be two features to really improve the game!

Crew:
You can hire certain characters to help you defending your train and they have lots of different skills and stats in which they can be leveled. Crew composition is great fun as it can give you the certain edge you need in certain situations. Leveling them however is a random choice between three random perks and you don't fully have control on how to level them. Furthermore crew size is limited to five members, which is enough but some skills need rebalancing as they significantly are more difficult to train and you'll get stuck with low level characters. It's easier to hire certain mid to high level characters, as they don't cost you weekly/monthly wages and are always waiting for you at the same location, once you know where to find them.

Conclusion:
Bounty Train runs really well and has only minor issues with stability, bugs or game fluidity which is a big pro. When playing you will come upon certain planed but not yet integrated features like different equipment for your crew members. I can only hope that in the future there will be more scenarios, game modes or additional content to choose from and that the variability of this game will be improved. I would even go so far to claim that I am willing to pay for additional DLCs to come as this game offers a unique and well done integration of different and enjoyable game concepts. And I would really regret to see its' potential wasted as in e.g. Cosmonautica. This game truely has a lot of potential, if improved in matters of content, balancing and variabilty as it hold some key elements to become a game that may even set standards. In its' current state it is really fun to play for about 30 hours play time, after that the replay factor declines rapidly. As off now it's not worth 25 bucks. However, you'll have to choose if you like games like this, if you want to support the developers or wait until completion or for a steam sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a big fan of Railroad Tycoon, I figured I'd check it out.

For an early access game, this game is extremely polished. In the 6 hours I played (4 hours and 2 hours consecutively), the game never crashed or froze. I did find a few oddities in the market screen but there were not any other bugs.

The gameplay itself is relatively straightforward, and the combat can be quite tough. After getting enough crew, I didn't have trouble defeating anything I came across but I could take significant damage. Trading is easy, but don't over do it. After picking up a second large cargo car, the tooltips began to be inaccurate as I would change the local economy if I used the same trade route a few times. But it is easy to go to a different station and start a different route.

There were some oddities with handling people in combat. Some of my crew  can crouch behind cover, others can't. I couldn't find anything in the character screen for why some could and some couldn't. The reloading is an odd mechanic and crew can't reload while walking. All in all, the combat was easy and toward the end I just started paying everyone off and getting invites to join their camps because the combat became too repetitive.

Pros:
- Stable
- Small learning curve
- Pretty
- Good tutorial (didn't finish it all, but very well done)
- Decent economy
- Okay crew AI
- Short (beat the campaign in 6 hours)

Cons:
- Crew can be a bit clunky
- Unintuitive station interface for moving crew/passengers off trains (didn't realize I could do this until I did it on accident)
- Needs keyboard bindings for dialogue (and some places, shouldn't have to wait for a response: looking at you City Hall)

Tl;dr Fun casual Sunday afternoon game that is currently stable and I will recommend to friends. 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far I can't recommend it, primarily due to in game pricing.  A newspaper costs as much as whole crates of some goods - and you must have a newspaper to get goods pricing in other towns (small issue, easily remedied).

The big issue (and the main reason I gave up after an hour) is that even IF you shell out the cash to get pricing info, do the market research and buy the goods - you STILL lose money (at least I did).  For example, if food" is selling in Boston for $10/unit and being bought in Portland (Maine
date: not Oregon - I'm not NEARLY that far yet
recommended: lol) for $15/unit - you should gross $5/unit. Not when I try it. Fill my cargo with food
voteText: click "sell" and it informs me that I will be selling for a loss.\n\nI know prices fluctuate - however
helpfulPercent: Portland is one town away from Boston on the map. I am also aware that some goods (like food) spoil. However
votesHelpful: Portland is only a few days' journey and "food" in the game supposedly takes a week to spoil.  I have yet to make any money (even simply gross profits
votesTotal: forget about net after deducting my expenses) buying and selling any goods.\n\nPortland and Boston are the only towns I have unlocked thus far
votesFunny: because my capital just keeps decreasing.\n\nOf course
commentsCount: if the economic mechanics change to something slightly less punishing (and less decepetive) I'll return and revise my review.  But I'm putting this frustration simulator aside until the next update."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will be looking forward to seeing this game completely finished in the future!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game, but still need some development. At short, some pros and contras for the game:

+
1. Interesting story, that gives great background for the family's story.
2. Good trains, routes and events on routes, but game is showing where and which one event will be presented on the route.
3. Good missions for deliveries, great missions to find and help the family to unite.
4. Quite good development system - you have a choise of skills each character's level, and frequently used skill can gain extra point.

-
1. No possibilities right now to improve trains and cabins, e.g. make additional armour, install turrels, etc
2. Strange balance between cabins and crew members - each new cabin allows you to hire only one extra-crew
3. No savegames at all - you can replay one fight, but cannot save progress on a timely basis, e.g. every game month.
4, Short story, and a lot of closed cities right now - I suppose that map will be expanded and family story will be much longer.
5. Price - quite high for a short playable time.

Right now I suggest to wait and see, how game will be developed. For this sum of money game must have bigger map, much longer history, better character progression sysetm and more trains.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOkay so i have played with Update 2 and also have uploaded a video on Steam and Youtube about it. For right now it is still not worth its asking price of 25 bucks. Since it first came out about a month ago, we have seen multiple versions, and the newest one is getting there. The money system got f***ked up again, The campaign is not worth going into detail about, the trading is the same, ETC... The combat however, IMPROVED DRASTICALLY!!!!! I mean they have patched the s**tty perks, and added a working Evasion perk, which is essentially the ability to dodge sometimes, kinda like Final Fantasy or Pokemon. also the SNADBOX mode is quite dissapointing, its more of a Free Roam thing, instead of a legit Sandbox. The rest can be explained in the video, which you can find in the Steam Videos for Bounty Train. SO Yeah, this game is so far a good 6/10, for its lack of content, and very low replayability. But still enjoyable nontheless. So pick it up when it either gets more content, or when its asking price is dropped, or on sale.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First look of Bounty Train. A train management game set in the Wild West. A deceptively easy game where you have to manage your train as it travels across the union and confederate states around the time of the civil war. You get attacked by bandits and Indians. You get to haul freight and passengers but more importantly you need to find your siblings so you can inherit a big bunch of cash and move back to England.

All in all, this deceptively simple game is a lot harder than it looks. And therefore more fun to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solid little game with decent visuals and flat learning curve. Game is mostly quest driven, although you can just drive around, trade and shoot bandits if you like. But that gets old quick. The story missions are nice and if you follow those missions you will quickly finish the game (like 5-6 hours I guess). I hope the final game gets more content, since it really is a unique mix of party based game with tactical combat, trade game and a some story-driven quests.

Role play elements include team members that can be leveled up and and tactical battles (real time with pause key) that are a lot of fun.

Sadly, there is little meat on the whole thing. Your party quickly maxes out after a few missions (with level 12 skills) and there are no items or inventory to otherwise improve upon them. They are also somewhat random and stay shallow, since they don't have indivudal quests or dialogues.

I suppose the game is aimed on casual gamers and beginners. Not much replayability at the moment I'm afraid. Also no free play" mode yet. Lets see what else they put in it."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While only an early access game at this point, Bounty Train is already a good game. Bounty Train mixes many different gameplay mechanics together to create a unique and fun gameplay experience. The three main mechanics in the game are probably train simulation, trading, and strategic combat.

The trading aspect of the game involves moving goods from town to town in order to sell them for a profit. You can also take missions that require you to deliver items to a certain city or pick up a certain type of good and bring it back to the city you picked up the mission. You may also pick up passengers and take them to their desired designation. The missions and passengers have a time limit though so you need to plan out your routes to make sure you complete them in time. If you take on too many missions at a time you will build yourself into a hole that you will be unable to get out of requiring you to restart the game.

The combat is pretty interesting. In each town you can hire people to join you to fight off bandits or other enemies you encounter. These characters gain stats as they fight like in an RPG. During combat you can decide where to position your people as well as pick which enemy you would like them to attack. At any time you can change where all of your people are located on your train.

Despite being an early access game, Bounty Train is already really polished. With some development time, Bounty Train could be a great game.

Note: I received a free review copy of Bounty Train. Other than receiving the free review copy, I received no other compensation for this review and the free copy had no impact on the content of this review.

Read My Full Review [www.geekyhobbies.com]
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game surpized me in a number of ways, firstly how god dayum awesome the UI is. Makes you feel as though your actaully operating a train! (Sorta) I also like how the combat is all in real time, at fist I was a bit skeptical as to if it should be turn based if things get out of control. The cover system and they position to fire from make it very manageble. The fact that its an open sand box on what some one would think to be a linear game just blew my mind. The random encounters are also pretty cray. One last feature that I really appreciate in this game is the Four factions, You have Indians/Aboriginals Confederacy, Union and Bandits. Depending on your actions of supplying/missions for whichever you choose be it one or a few you can gain allies and boons and also enemies. (makes me want to have a Rebellion Train for the Confeds, and a Union Train for Freedom!) All in all a very competent game an Early Access title worthy of early entry!

30 Minutes or Less, I adore the UI in this game!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lwrebjA999M

Thanks so much for reading my review, hope it helps. I am curious to if they eventaully add the mid-west/ west which would be great! What would also be awesome sauce if they bring it up to the year 1911 which is essentially the end of the wild west.

About 10hrs in, once Ive upgraded my train a few timnes, unlocked some cities, and hired a decent crew, I dont think there will be much to motivate me to go on & keep playing, Perhaps if my train was one among several I could own and set to work in an expanding business empire? That might be fun. Heck, maybe it is and I just havent got to that yet? But I doubt it.
Sometimes I take a mission and my train just isnt fast enough to get there, would be nice to know that in advace. Almost never engage in 'normal' trade as its not very profitable.
Fighting is fun but happens way too often now, I feel like every trip im in a 10 minute battle which is draining and gets repeatative. The factions seem like reskins of each other, what's the difference between bandits and indians? nothing. No unique personality or chance to side with one or the other. May they could think of other challenges or obsticals between cities.
It might sound like I'm bagging out this game, I'm not, I love the game, but I want it to reach its potential. Ats it stands, around 10 hours in I'm looking for something else to keeep me interested.
Also the auto game saving system without letting the player save/load is so damn frustrating.
Looking forward to the finished version!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's hard to not recommend this game because it is everything it promises - an open-world, squad management RPG on trains. However, there has not been an update in over 2 months and the game gets rather repetitive. I also found situations where I was hunting down bandits and they disappear from the map altogether, meaning I was unable to finish the quest.

If this is your type of game, feel free to get it. It is not anywhere near as polished as FTL but it's definitely a title worth keeping an eye on.

6/10 at the moment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated 2-9-16:  Update 4 has improved the game significantly.  I actually played through until I ran out of time to complete the campaign.  I was pretty strategic about progressing but I doubt more than 5% could win the main campaign.

Issues:
1) Still too expensive to purchase new routes.
2) Steel slows down the trains soooo much that it takes numerous trips just to build up the steel you need in Memphis.  While the mechanics make sense of weight/distance, the idea that there aren't refuel stations nearly everywhere is crazy.  Either increase the tenders sizes, increase the number of cities, or allow midpoint refueling locations.
3) The duration before the stockholder meeting is extremely agressive.  The current duration could work if you increased the value of town hall missions by about 50% or decreased the cost of new routes by 50%.

A couple more revisions and I would consider recommending this game to others.
